thread.title: 'Working poor' facing greater struggle to put food on table: Foodbank Tasmania
thread.title_full: 'Working poor' facing greater struggle to put food on table: Foodbank Tasmania

author: Linda Hunt
title: 'Working poor' facing greater struggle to put food on table: Foodbank Tasmania
text:
Map: Hobart 7000 
One of the state's largest food and relief organisations, Foodbank Tasmania, experienced a 60 per cent jump in demand in January compared with last year. 
Chief executive director Edward Gauden said demand usually dropped as a result of increased support during the holiday season, but not this year. 
"We normally take a bit of a break like everyone else but we found that agencies were on our doorstep at 8:30am on the 27th (December)," Mr Gauden said. 
"That's just flown through from December to January." 
Fifty-thousand kilograms of food was distributed by the organisation last month alone, providing more than 65,000 meals to Tasmanians in need. 
"The number of meals have been ... far more increased and also it's not only just the meals its the other utensils, hygiene products even toiletries," Mr Gauden said. 
Back to school has also meant high demand for the school breakfast program, which provides a healthy breakfast to more than 4,000 students in 96 schools. 
"Today has been incredibly busy supplying those schools with food," Mr Gauden said. 
The increase in demand is a worrying trend for organisations like Foodbank Tasmania. 
Mr Gauden said more Tasmanians were struggling to put food on the table. 
"It just seems that there is a working poor now," he said. 
"People that have had good jobs have less hours, others are actually trying to work a lot more to support their families, pay the hydro, school fees, school clothes, school shoes." 
The organisation is now even more reliant on the generosity of the wider community to help meet demand. 
"You know, farmers to donate those little extra products that they may seem to be seconds, or individuals that can actually give some time up to come in to the Foodbank and pack hampers," Mr Gauden said.
